updates.message: Phase I/IIa Gene Therapy for CLN3 Batten Disease (CLN-301)
Drafted email to Amy Vierhile, RN PNP
Drafted email to Nationwide Children's Hospital CLN-301 Trial Team
Drafted email to NIH Clinical Center, Office of Patient Recruitment
NIH Office of Orphan Products Development (OOPD) Grant: $600,000/year for up to 4 years
Beyond Batten Disease Foundation Spring Grant Cycle: $5,000 - $50,000 (family support and research grants)

approvalQueue.title: Email to Amy Vierhile - Baseline UBDRS Evaluation
approvalQueue.summary: Request for baseline clinical evaluation at University of Rochester. Amy Vierhile is the leading CLN3 clinician with 20+ years experience. Her UBDRS assessments are the gold standard referenced by all trial sponsors.

content.subject: CLN3 Batten Disease Baseline Evaluation - Urgent
content.body:
Dear Amy,

Our child was recently diagnosed with CLN3 Batten Disease, and we've been researching the best first steps. Your work at the University of Rochester—particularly your longitudinal natural history study spanning over two decades—stands out as the gold standard for understanding CLN3 progression.

We understand that establishing a baseline UBDRS score is critical for trial eligibility assessment across multiple emerging therapies (PLX-200, Batten-1, CLN-301 gene therapy). We would like to bring our child to Rochester for evaluation.

Could we schedule an assessment in the coming weeks? We're aware of your study's enrollment and would be grateful for any guidance on timing.

Thank you for your work in this space.

Best regards,
[Family Name]

approvalQueue.title: Email to Nationwide Children's Hospital CLN-301 Team
approvalQueue.summary: Express interest in CLN-301 trial and request information about enrollment likelihood and alternative pathways. Trial currently active but not recruiting.

content.subject: CLN3 Batten Disease - Interest in CLN-301 Trial and Future Enrollment
content.body:
Dear CLN-301 Trial Team,

Our child was recently diagnosed with CLN3 Batten Disease. We've reviewed the published CLN-301 Phase I/II results and are deeply moved by the data showing treated patients remaining stable (UBDRS -0.22 points/year) compared to natural history (2.86 points/year)—truly remarkable outcomes.

We understand CLN-301 is currently active but not recruiting. We wanted to reach out to express our strong interest should enrollment reopen and to learn about alternative pathways or future trial opportunities through Alcyone Therapeutics.

Our child meets the inclusion criteria (age, UBDRS score, able to walk independently). Could you advise on: (1) likelihood of reopening enrollment? (2) criteria you'll use for prioritization? (3) other trial pathways you recommend in the interim?

We're prepared to begin baseline clinical evaluation immediately.

Thank you for this life-changing work.

Best regards,
[Family Name]

approvalQueue.title: Email to NIH Clinical Center - Natural History Study Enrollment
approvalQueue.summary: Request enrollment in CLN3 Natural History Study (NCT03307304). This is the foundational clinical evaluation that connects families to all trial sponsors and provides comprehensive biomarker data.

content.subject: CLN3 Batten Disease Enrollment in NIH Natural History Study
content.body:
Dear Office of Patient Recruitment,

Our child was recently diagnosed with CLN3 Batten Disease. We've learned about the NIH Clinical Center's CLN3 Natural History Study (NCT03307304) and believe enrollment would be invaluable for our family and for advancing CLN3 research.

From our research, we understand the study:
- Accepts patients of any age
- Collects comprehensive biomarker data (genetics, retinal imaging, CSF, blood, urine)
- Connects families directly to trial sponsors and researchers worldwide
- Covers all travel costs

Could we begin the enrollment process? We are prepared to travel to Bethesda as soon as appointments are available.

Please advise on next steps. You can reach us at [contact info].

Thank you,
[Family Name]

approvalQueue.title: Email to Polaryx Therapeutics - PLX-200 Phase 3 Enrollment Interest
approvalQueue.summary: Request information about PLX-200 Phase 3 trial enrollment opening March 2026. PLX-200 is an oral small-molecule therapy with FDA Fast Track designation—the most accessible near-term option.

content.subject: CLN3 Batten Disease - Interest in PLX-200 Phase 3 Trial Enrollment
content.body:
Dear Polaryx Therapeutics,

Our child was recently diagnosed with CLN3 Batten Disease. We learned about PLX-200 and your upcoming Phase 3 trial opening in March 2026, and we're interested in learning more about enrollment eligibility.

We're drawn to PLX-200 because:
- It's oral (non-invasive compared to intrathecal therapies)
- FDA Fast Track designation accelerates development
- Phase 3 trial includes children ages 6-18, which matches our child's profile
- Preliminary data suggests meaningful efficacy

Our child meets the general inclusion criteria for mild-to-moderate CLN3 disease. Could you provide:

1. Detailed eligibility criteria for Phase 3 enrollment?
2. Geographic trial sites nearest to [location]?
3. Timeline and process for screening and enrollment?
4. Contact for patient advocacy partnership?

We are preparing comprehensive baseline clinical data and are ready to proceed rapidly.

Thank you,
[Family Name]

approvalQueue.title: Email to Beyond Batten Disease Foundation - Family & Research Support
approvalQueue.summary: Request immediate support for treatment pathway guidance, trial coordination, family network connection, and information about research partnership opportunities. Beyond Batten is the most critical ally.

content.subject: New CLN3 Batten Disease Diagnosis - Seeking Family & Research Support
content.body:
Dear Beyond Batten Disease Foundation,

Our family was recently devastated by our child's CLN3 Batten Disease diagnosis. In our research, your foundation emerges as the most trusted voice in the CLN3 community—not only because of your direct family support, but because of your extraordinary achievement in bringing Batten-1 to the clinical stage.

We need guidance on several fronts:

1. **Immediate Clinical Pathway**: We're evaluating CLN-301 (gene therapy), PLX-200 (oral small molecule), and Batten-1 (miglustat). How do you recommend we sequence these options given our child's current disease stage?

2. **Trial Coordination**: Which trials are most accessible right now for our geographic location [state]? How do we prioritize enrollment?

3. **Family Network**: We would benefit enormously from connecting with other CLN3 families who have navigated these same decisions.

4. **Research Partnership**: We understand your foundation funds research and provides grant opportunities. Are there ways we could support or participate in ongoing research initiatives?

Would it be possible to schedule a call with someone on your family support team?

Thank you for all you do.

Best regards,
[Family Name]

approvalQueue.title: Beyond Batten Disease Foundation - Family Support & Research Grant (Draft LOI)
approvalQueue.summary: Request for $15,000-$25,000 to cover clinical baseline evaluation, genetic counseling, NIH enrollment travel, and family support coordination. This is the most immediate and highest-probability funding source for the family's first 90 days of care.

approvalQueue.title: Chan Zuckerberg Initiative - Rare As One Network Community Grant (Concept Note)
approvalQueue.summary: Proposal to build CLN3 family navigation platform with CZI funding ($150K over 18 months). This is a longer-term strategic initiative to scale Beacon to 50+ CLN3 families and contribute to rare disease research infrastructure.

approvalQueue.title: NIH NINDS R21 Exploratory Research - CLN3 Biomarker Discovery (Concept Note)
approvalQueue.summary: NIH research grant proposal ($350K over 3 years) to establish CLN3 natural history cohort and identify biomarkers predictive of treatment response. This supports academic research infrastructure and feeds into trial design for all CLN3 programs.
